quiz.title: Physics 11: Unit 3 Quiz 6
quiz.subtitle: Levers – Mechanical Advantage, Velocity Ratio, and Efficiency
quiz.subject: Physics 11

questions.question: A first-class lever has the fulcrum 0.3 m from a 400 N load and 0.9 m from the effort. What is the ideal mechanical advantage (MA)?
questions.explanation: Ideal MA = Effort arm length / Load arm length = 0.9 m / 0.3 m = 3.0

questions.question: The same lever lifts the 400 N load 0.1 m while the effort moves 0.35 m. What is the actual mechanical advantage?
questions.explanation: Actual MA = Load / Effort. Work in = Work out if 100% efficient: Effort × 0.35 m = 400 N × 0.1 m → Effort ≈ 114.29 N. Actual MA = 400 / 114.29 ≈ 2.29.

questions.question: For the lever in questions 1–2, what is the efficiency (as a percentage)?
A second-class lever has the load between fulcrum and effort. If the load is 0.4 m from the fulcrum and effort is 1.2 m from the fulcrum, what is the velocity ratio (VR)?
questions.explanation: VR = Distance moved by effort / Distance moved by load = Effort arm / Load arm = 1.2 / 0.4 = 3.0

questions.question: A lever system has VR = 4 and efficiency = 80%. What actual MA does it provide?
A worker applies 150 N of effort to lift a 450 N crate using a lever. What is the actual mechanical advantage?
questions.explanation: Actual MA = Load / Effort = 450 N / 150 N = 3.0

questions.question: In the lever above, if the effort moves 0.6 m to lift the crate 0.15 m, what is the velocity ratio?
questions.explanation: VR = Distance effort moves / Distance load moves = 0.6 m / 0.15 m = 4.0

questions.question: Using the same numbers (MA = 3, VR = 4), what is the efficiency of the lever?
A third-class lever has MA less than 1. If the effort arm is 0.25 m and load arm is 0.75 m, what is the ideal MA?
questions.explanation: Ideal MA = Effort arm / Load arm = 0.25 / 0.75 = 1/3 ≈ 0.33

questions.question: If a lever system is 60% efficient and has VR = 5, how much effort is needed to lift a 300 N load?
questions.explanation: MA = Efficiency × VR = 0.60 × 5 = 3.0. Effort = Load / MA = 300 N / 3 = 100 N

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You’ve mastered lever MA, VR, and efficiency concepts.
scoreMessages.70: Very good! Solid understanding; review the efficiency formula (MA/VR)×100%.
scoreMessages.50: Fair. Practice distinguishing between actual MA, ideal MA, and VR.
scoreMessages.0: Review lever classes, MA = Load/Effort, VR = Effort arm/Load arm.
